results.title: Researching the story
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode overviews the first part of storytelling - finding a story people can relate to. It describes research techniques such as defining what is a story, story telling styles, finding the angle, getting the facts, developing sources, finding the people, preparing the shoot, briefing the crew and meeting deadlines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: Shooting on location
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode looks at light and how the camera responds to it. It shows how to get good pictures shooting at night and using light creatively.

results.title: Video sound
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode looks at background noise and how to reduce it. It explains the uses of single, wide or omni-directional microphones, extension mikes and their placement (especially with interviews or music), directional mikes and how to use them together effectively.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.description:

results.title: The Moving camera, the moving subject
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode looks at the art of shooting movement. The composition of shots with a moving subject, such as walking room and depth of field, what happens when the subject moves, and how to deal with holding the action and combinations of movements are highlighted. Demonstrates the techniques of using a moving camera, such as tripod moves, zooming and tracking.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.description:

results.title: The Camera and the tripod
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode deals with what the camera sees - focus and shot sizes, how to make pictures look better and how to zoom, pan and tilt.

results.title: Introduction to video
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Video tech”.
This introductory episode provides a basic outline of the various formats, how videotapes actually work, different sorts of video cameras - betacam, professional cams, consumer cams, the camcorder, and how to get good sound on the videotape.

results.title: Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coast Community College
results.brief_description: This series examines the history and science of astronomy. It includes superb graphics, photographs and time-lapse footage from satellites and observatories, and leading scientists in the various fields of astronomy offer clear explanations and valuable information.

results.title: Life on other worlds
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Does life exist elsewhere in the universe? The search for life begins by looking for the chemicals of life - hydrogen and helium, which emanate from the stars. The atoms which make up our body, come directly from the stars, when supernovae exploded and dispersed their atoms into the molecular clouds around them. This chemical cocktail is the beginning of life. Astronomers are searching the heavens for this chemical cocktail and for signals from distant galaxies similar to our own. Ultimately this may show, that in all probability, we are not alone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges

results.title: Meteorites, asteroids and comets
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 25 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Meteorites have crashed to the Earth since time began with massive craters proving this, although scientists initially found it difficult to believe. Once it was determined that the rocks were “out of this world”, serious study was given to the phenomena. The location of the asteriod belt between Mars and Jupiter implies the existence of a now disintegrated planet. These asteriods are composed of three types: silicate, metal and carbon based. Comets have always been seen as “emissaries of chaos”. Halley’s Comet has offered scientists a chance to study this celestial body, which is largely an ice ball on an orbit through space. Comets have been known to cause destruction upon impact, and scientists believe that such a collision, which would result in mass devastation, may have explained the sudden extinction of dinosaurs on Earth. The likelihood of such an event re-occuring is also discussed.

results.title: Uranus, Neptune and Pluto
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
William Herschel dicovered the planet Uranus in the late 1700’s. In 1986, the satellite Voyager flew past and sent back pictures of this ice planet. Neptune and Uranus have similar composition, but Uranus, unlike other planets, has an unusual rotation and large tilt, where it may have been hit by a celestial object. Uranus has rings and around it floats the debris from the formation of the solar system. Neptune, although similar to Uranus, has a different atmosphere and a dark spot, similar to Jupiter, as well as thin ring arcs. Triton, one of Neptune’s moons, is the coldest place in the solar system. Pluto was the last planet to be discovered, and because Voyager did not pass by, scientists have had to use other methods such as spectroscopy to determine its composition. It is the smallest planet in our solar system and may be a remanant of planet formation when the solar system was first formed.
